oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Aerial view of downtown Nashville, Tennessee, 1954
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: An aerial view of the Tennessee State Capitol, located at 600 Charlotte Avenue in the central business district of downtown Nashville, Tennessee circa 1954. Part of the Andrew Jackson Hotel is pictured (on right). The State Capitol was constructed between 1845 and 1859. It was designed in Greek Revival style by architect William Strickland (1788-1854). Strickland died before construction was completed and was interred in the walls of the north portico. His son, Francis W. Strickland, oversaw the completion of the project. The cupola was reputedly modeled on a Greek monument to Lysicrates and designed to be illuminated at night like a lantern. The building was constructed of Tennessee Limestone and underwent major restoration for 1956-1960. During the restoration, much of the limestone, including most in the cupola and the Ionic columns and capitals, was replaced with Indiana limestone. The grounds contain monuments to famous people and events in Tennessee history. The Capitol was placed on the National Register of Historic Places in 1970. North Nashville can be seen in the distance. Forms part of Record Group 3, Metro Davidson County Photographer. 1 photograph negative : b & w ; 4 x 5 in.
